comments.text:
+Paul-Octave Hébert Germany would have stood by Austria, no matter what, as 
Catholic Austria was "just kicked out" of Germany by Protestant Prussia, 
but both the Germans and Austrians considered themselves to be one German 
people. This is highly relevant, even when talking about WWII and plays a 
huge role into how Germany, Switzerland, and Austria interact with one 
another even today.

At the same time, Germany would have attacked France, no matter what, as 
Germany and France had been rivals eversince Charlelemagne split its empire 
into what would later be France, Germany, and Italy. Since then both France 
and Germany tried to conquer the other. The treaty of Versailles of 1918 
was a response to the previous treaty of Versailles from when Prussia beat 
France, a war that started because France was occupying Germany, which was 
a result of .... you get the picture. It wasn't until the Treaty of 1963 
that both nations finally left this rivalry behind them and try their best 
that future generations won't play the blame game.

Germans, however, didn't have a problem with the British. Prior the war, 
the German national anthemn, "Heil Dir im Siegerkranz" was using the exact 
same melody as the British "God save the King". During the war, the British 
crown even had to change their German surname during WWI to highlight to 
the British people that they were, in fact, not siding with Germany.

Germany's entire conflict with Great Britain during this time rests solely 
on the shoulders of Wilhelm II who thought that his British side of the 
family is at fault for his birth deformity. Wilhelm also turned out to be a 
horrible leader who saw this war as a game, and kept sending letters to his 
cousin "Nicki", as he called him, the tsar of Russia, despite him being the 
supposed enemy. Furthermore, Willhelm also only used the German navy once, 
then never again as those were his favorite troops. And it was also Wilhelm 
who went against Bismarck's policies and insisted on Germany having 
colonies abroad, which he ended up losing at the end of WWI. Naturally, the 
Germans grew weary of such a leader and feared that only a democracy could 
prevent another such ruler, which is why, for Germany, the war ended with 
the abolishment of monarchy and the founding of the Weimar Republic.

comments.text:
+adugan22
The point is Russia had no formal alliance with Serbia. So Russia had no 
legal obligation whatsoever to support Serbia. It supported Serbia because 
it had a 'pan-Slavist' outlook i.e. the Russian Czar saw himself, and set 
himself up, as the protector of the Slavic peoples. Having done that, he 
would lose face if Russia then failed to support Serbia. Yes, a pretty 
flimsy reason to risk a huge war!

You ask why Russia wouldn't mobilize asap whilst the Austrians were on 
"harvest leave"? I'd say here the point is the alliance system. Germany DID 
have a formal alliance with Austria. An attack on Austria would bring in 
Germany, Europe's strongest military Power! The Russians should have 
thought long and hard before mobilizing their army because why risk a war 
with Germany? Just so the Czar could look strong and play the great 
protector? I say again, a flimsy reason to put your country at risk!

Did Serbia even deserve support given it was a Serbian secret society (the 
'Black Hand') that had given covert assistance to the bunch of assassins 
one of whom murdered the Austrian crown-prince?

Having said all that, the Germans also took a big risk with their 'blank 
cheque' of support to the Austrians! The Russian Czar and German Kaiser 
were both weak men trying to look strong! And they both were getting very 
bad advice from the people around them! So Russia & Germany failed to apply 
adequate restraint to Serbia & Austria.

Battle of Morgarten (1315), Battle of Sempach (1386), Old Zurich War 
(1440-1446), Burgundian Wars (1474-1477), Swabian War (1511-1516), the 
Hundred Days (1815), Sonderbund War (1847)... all of these included the 
Swiss as aggressors...﻿
top_comment.author: Cj Collum

comments.author: Alany Walany

comments.text:
+Alany Walany you're correct, but I have reasons for their inclusion.

The Hundred Days campaign was referenced simply by virtue of Swiss 
involvement, although I suppose the implication was Swiss aggression, so I 
can understand your objection to its inclusion.

The Sonderbund War I thought I had removed from my list, although, upon 
further reflection, I'm glad I left it in. You are correct that it was a 
civil war, but regardless of who the combatants are in a conflict (in this 
case the protestant Confederacy and the seven catholic cantons collectively 
known as the Sonderbund; for those unfamiliar with the war), war is still 
war. Additionally, given some of the things that occurred as a result of 
the Sonderbund War (establishment of the Swiss federal state, founding of 
the Red Cross, etc.), I feel its inclusion is rather necessary, regardless 
of whether the war was Swiss vs. Swiss. Furthermore, leaving the Sonderbund 
War off the list would imply that other great civil wars (e.g. the American 
Revolution, Rwandan civil war, Glyndwr Rising, etc.,) don't count either. 
Imagine how much different the world would be today without the conflict.
comments.author: Cj Collum

comments.text:

comments.author: Bird_Dog

comments.text:
+Bird_Dog​ about Morgarten, strictly speaking it was simply the first 
battle of the Habsburg Wars, but it qualifies as Swiss agression in the 
context of my original post. But you're not wrong in phrasing it the way 
you did, as that is largely precisely what happened to lead the Habsburg 
army to be caught in a confederate ambush.

And you are again correct in stating that it's an oversimplification, but 
there is no denying that the agressive territorial expansion of the Swiss 
at the time played a rather significant role.

My point wasn't in the specifics of each example (as nothing in history is 
simple by any means). Rather, it was a counterpoint to the popular notion 
that Switzerland is some peaceful nation that has always been neutral. It 
isn't really peaceful (they have half the country rigged with explosives to 
deter invasion) and, historically, they were pretty violent (like much the 
of the world at the time, to be fair).

I suppose I could have simply reminded people that the Swiss Guard still 
exists (and aren't just there to make the Pope look cool), but history is 
more fun.﻿

Edit: clarification

comments.text:
Tzar Romanov was responsible for Russia's backing of Serbs. And believe it 
or not he did it 100% out of emotional reasons. Politically, Serbia stopped 
integrating with Russia's economy and culture ever since it's de jure 
independence in 1878. and turned to France as a role-model of development. 
But after Bosnian crysis 1908. Russia became more interested in the affairs 
in the Balkans and wanted to revive the mid-19th century 'brotherhood'. 
This was not going well for them as long as France and Britain kept 
investing in Serbia and backing it up. Things changed only after Balkan 
wars - Britain put a collar on Serbia in those wars and did not allow it to 
integrate certain territories which were won and controlled by its 
military. Serbian government's main goal was to gain as much of territory 
near the sea coast as possible. But Britania, ruler of the seas, did not 
want anyone else in the Mediterranean and Serbia had progressed in its 
territorial gains way to fast for their liking. France and Britain just 
wanted the Ottomans out. Once that was over, there was no need for the 
formation of a new powerful, unified Balkan state (goal of Serbia: 
Yugoslavia). They wanted only small nations in the Balkans (easy to 
control). Post WW1 Yugoslavia happened only because USA strongarmed Britain 
and France into accepting that idea. Britain was only allowing Serbia to 
integrate Bosnia, but had to withdraw in the end. France also pushed for 
the disintegration of AU and succeeded.

The Russian Tzar backed the Serbs because he had romantic ideals about 
common origins (not that it isn't true, it just was not pragmatic at the 
time) and purpose: one day there would be a nation of all Slavs led by 
Russia - bolsheviks kinda messed this up with the USSR, although USSR was 
still a pretty strong nation. It just was not unified under the ideals 
Romanov hoped for.

+Blah b Yes, I want to learn. But you'll have to provide a lot better 
evidence than supposition to make me believe the US would go to war with 
the UK, a major trade partner, for what? Some goats in the Falklands?

"Why would a country try to build the biggest fleet of battleships unless 
they're trying to build for a war to outfight the country with the biggest 
fleet?"
The purpose a navy is first and foremost to project power. Your assumption 
on where that power was intended to be projected is unfounded. Just look at 
the current US navy. It vastly outclasses any other navy, furthermore 
several of the runners up are allies. Do you think the people in charge of 
the US navy are idiots because there is no other navy of comparable size to 
fight? Having such a large fleet allows for the US to bring a swift end to 
conflicts against second rate opponents using overwhelming force and to 
project power simultaneously in multiple theaters.

America's policy during that era was for Europe to do it's thing and leave 
the Americas alone. The UK didn't threaten any US interests abroad.
comments.author: SpazzyMcGee1337

comments.text:
+SpazzyMcGee1337
Why would a country try to build the biggest fleet of battleships unless 
they're trying to build for a war to outfight the country with the biggest 
fleet?

There is no reason. You only start such a building program if you're 
gearing up for war for Great Britain, like the United States was at the 
time.

As for the rest, listen, do you want to learn, or do you want to 'look' 
while keeping your eyes covered tightly because you've already made up your 
mind?
comments.author: Blah b

comments.text:
+Blah b I just can't see how you are drawing any of these conclusions. 
Building battleships is very very far from "proof" that America was going 
to start a war with the UK. The America's policy back then was for Europe 
to stay out of the Americas and for the Americas to stay out of European 
business. Two large fleets protecting the separate interests of two nations 
is not a prelude to war.

As for that submarine, I can't even fathom what you are getting at with 
this. The page says nothing about spies, the submarine was an unarmed trade 
vessel carrying medical supplies, and the fact that its third mission to 
the USA was canceled due to poor American-German relations undermines 
whatever it is you are trying to say.

Finally, all nations are driven by economics and you make it sound like the 
US government was only privy to American economic interests until the last 
second.

The conclusions you are making are absurd. It almost sounds like you are a 
paranoid British nationalist trying to reinterpret history as the story of 
Britian against the world.
comments.author: SpazzyMcGee1337

comments.text:
+SpazzyMcGee1337
No, I'm saying the US was gearing up for war with Great Britain because 
they wanted to take over world domination. Proven by their battleship 
building program for example.

Their trade policies in WW I, allowing German agents to operate openly on 
US soil, and some other things, show they were openly pro-German.

This is illustrated by the Deutschland's reception in the US for example:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_submarine_Deutschland

The crew was heralded in as heroes by the Americans, and the submarine even 
operated for wartime operations from American ports. (doesn't this conflict 
with the idea that German submarine operations made the US change its mind? 
It does)


It's only when it was discovered by the American administration that the US 
economy (mostly through the stock market) had billions riding on an allied 
victory, that the attitude began to change.
Here's a bit of detail on that:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_entry_into_World_War_I#Business_considerations

top_comment.author: CrimsonVocals

comments.text:
You have a good point, I'll give you that. And at least in my opinion the 
single good thing about communism is that it focuses on finding a place for 
everyone and attempting to not leave anyone behind. But then again, do some 
people deserve to get left behind? There are people who are hard-working 
and people who are lazy, so if we give the lazy person the same benefits we 
give to the hard-working, wouldn't that destroy the hard-working one's 
morale? The most important thing about capitalism is that it is a "natural" 
system and therefore it forces individuals and companies to compete with 
each other. Even though it is a cruel system, it is a working system.
I would argue that even in this new "mechanized" future, humans would still 
have jobs. If not as workers in production then as mechanics for the 
machines in production. And as machines get more effective and cheaper, 
companies invest on more machines and therefore more people in design, 
production and maintenance of these machines. When the steam engine and 
factories first were invented people were afraid that it would make the 
factory workers obsolete, and they were right. But are 90% of the people 
out of job nowadays? No they aren't, because new jobs were created on the 
fields that the mechanization of the previous fields had made possible. 
More people began to work on "serving" jobs such as restaurants, clubs, 
movie theaters, supermarkets ...You name it! No-one could have even 
imagined in the 19th century that someone could work as an "IT-support 
person", but still somehow they do.
The free market is a strange and wonderful tool in my opinion and I 
continue to believe in it! :)
comments.author: Markus FIN

comments.text:
+Markus FIN
Have you read the collected works of Marx and Engles, in which they 
pontificate on these issues more fully?

I am not saying Communism is perfect but, then again, most capitalist 
philosophers were pretty wrong about the way markets work, especially 
hundreds of years later.

Marx's and Engles' ideas will become more pertinent in a society where 
humans are obsolesced by machines/computers. How does an economy work when 
the economy and society as a whole only need a tiny fraction to survive, 
exist and perpetuate itself? How does Democracy, Capitalism - modernity, 
really - survive in a world where 90% of a population are a drain on 
society as a whole?

You then have to look at other systems to make society function. Is that 
Communism?

At its heart Communism is about ensuring everyone has a function in 
society, that no one is left behind and everyone is treated equally. It is 
a direct response to the way industrialization was destroying traditional 
life-ways and turning people into cogs in a great machine.

In the same way, we are looking to a future where human cogs are no longer 
needed in that machine. Computers will do the vast majority of manual labor 
(cleaning, driving, manufacturing, service industry, etc.), infringe on our 
jobs that are traditionally occupied by educated people (teaching, 
medicine, computing, code writing, middle management, engineering, the 
military, etc.) and even seep into "creative" fields (like music) in the 
future.

Communism, or more specifically something vaguely like Communism in the 
broad strokes, makes more sense in a future where having a job is something 
that simply will not exist for the vast majority of people. You must 
re-order how society functions on a fundamental level.

comments.text:
Communism:

Pros:
-Eliminates most of the class society that usually appears in states with 
free market.
-In it's early days can provide a better standard of life for it's citizens.
-Eliminates inequalities in wealth completely.

Cons:
-Usually requires violence in order to be kept in power.
-The inability to gain personal wealth causes massive collapse in working 
morale and therefore creates a nation-wide epidemic of low working morale.
-Gives little to no value to the freedom of an individual.

Democracy/Capitalism:

Pros:
-Gives high value to personal freedom and lifts the individual above the 
society.
-Usually on the long run leads to a massive rise in the standard of life 
for most of the people.
-Works decently in practice and gives everyone a chance to participate in 
the making of nation-wide decisions.

Cons:
-Can occasionally lead to extreme wealth inequalities.
-Is vulnerable to booms and busts which can create a feeling of insecurity 
in people.
-Can be inefficient when it comes to making fast and radical decisions as 
there is always a need to compromise.
comments.author: Markus FIN

comments.text:
+Ben B Allright, hate to have to do this to you, and hate to have to spend 
time on this rather uninteresting subject. But here we go.

FIrst off, lets get some facts straight and educate you a little bit.

The geopolitical deterent system that was in place in 1914 consisted of 
several alliances, that up to a degree had been in flux. But at the time of 
the war the situation, speaking in very broad terms, was like this: On the 
one hand you had the Franco-English-Russian alliance and on the other hand 
you had the German-Austrian/Hungarian alliance who had a wavering partner 
in the Italians and a, by all considerd very weak, partner in the Ottomans 
(the English can be considerd a wavering partner in the opposing alliance, 
but they turned out to be rather unflinching when the fighting started). 

So these opposing blocks where all very much aware of there respective 
military capability's. One of the important factors when considering these 
military capability's was considerd to be the mobilization speed (and the 
railroad systems that facilitated them.).When one country mobilized, the 
other countries had to mobilize in return in order not to be overrun. Very 
important factor to keep in mind for later on. 

Allright, so the English and the French had developed a joint mobilization 
plan, of which offcourse the Germans and the entire population of all 
involved nations where aware. They allready had mass media in those days. 
The Germans had made counter plans to deal with this double threat, of 
which they knew it was to much to handle in the case of a two front war. 
This counter plan involved a quick march through Belgium in to France, 
cutting of the English assistance on which the French where counting to tip 
the balance in their favour. 
Obviously the English and the French where fully aware as well of the 
German mobilization plans and their strategey to counter their joint 
mobilization plan. In fact, it is important to note that the Germans had no 
contingency plan, this was there plan A and B. Of which the French, 
Russians and the English where also fully aware. The point being here that 
the Germans could not envision any other way of dealing with the situation. 

Allright, having said all of that we can now move to the other front. The 
eastern front. 
After the assasination the Austrian/Hungarian empire felt it was forced to 
respond. They, after much ado, orderd a partial mobilization, stricly 
focussed on Serbia, which was responsible for the assasination of the heir. 
Small point to make here, just because it is important to me personally. 
The main reason the Serbs assasinated the archduke was because he was a 
moderate. And by being a moderate he would decrease the resistance to the 
Austrian/Hungarian empire, thereby making it more difficult for the Serbs 
to stir up nationalism and anti Austrian/Hungarian sentiment, on which they 
relied to further their dreams of a large Serbia, and we all know what a 
great idea that was. So again a case that proves a point made in a earlier 
crash course episode about the dangers of being a moderate. 
But enough of this little side track. The Austrian/Hungarian empire orderd 
a partial mobilization and was about to punish the Serbs for assasinating 
the heir to their kingdom. The Russians felt like they had to protect their 
spere of influence in the Balkans and had to protect the Serbs. Key factor 
to note here is that the Serbs did not dare to reject the ultimatum send by 
the Austrian/Hungarians untill they had assurances from the Russians that 
they would interefere and had started their "pre-mobilization" plans. The 
same can btw be said about the Austrian/Hungarians, they only dared to do a 
partial mobilization after they had assurances from the Germans that they 
would back them. The Germans at this point thought it was a) fair enough 
that the Austrian/Hungarians responded to the assasination and b) that if 
they stould firmly at the side of their ally it would reduce the chances of 
an all out war. 

Allright, having said all of that. After the Austrian/Hungarians declared 
war on Serbia the Russians fully mobilized (a full mobilization also 
entailed a mobilization directed at the heart of Germany). The same day the 
French also started mobilizing. The Germans then even waited a full day, 
which in terms of the mobilization rates and speeds of those days was a 
gigantic military gamble, which they took because they still hoped that 
there would be a peacefull and diplomatic solution (they where offcourse 
fully aware that they where in the underdog position in the case of a two 
front war).

After all of that they also felt forced to mobilize. At this time the 
Austrian/Hungarians and the Serbs where allready fighting and the Russians 
where preparing to invade both Austrian/Hungary and Germany, and the French 
where also preparing to invade the Germans (they had allready fully 
mobilized and considering the capability's of their railroad networks, the 
Germans had perhaps one or two more days to respond, else they would not 
 be able to stop even the French from marching straight in to Berlin within 
a month). 

So everybody at this point knew, the Great war was on. The Germans knew as 
well and they also mobilized and enacted their one and only contingency 
plan that allowed them some hope of victory. A quick march threw Belgium 
with some swift victory's over the French, cutting of the English support 
and then focussing on, what was considerd to be the more serious threat, 
the eastern front. 

The Germans send an ultimatum to the Belgiums, demanding acces due to "the 
grave and historical circumstances". The Belgiums, being spurred one by the 
English who assured them of their support refused. The Germans enterd 
anyways, declaring war on the Russians, the French and the Belgiums. Which 
was then used as a casus beli by the English political elite to convince a 
prior to that unconviced English public, to also enter the war. They then 
proceeded to enact their joint mobilization plan with the French, which the 
political elite of the Enlgish had always been planning on doing. The 
Germans never even managed to cut swiftly through Belgium, because the 
English and the French where there soon enough to cut them off. 

So yes, you are correct, the Germans where the first to declare war. They 
indeed did invade a "neutral" country (Belgium). But for the rest, your 
standpoints on these matters clearly indicate a lacking historical 
awareness. 

I could further debate with you on matters such as the possible existence 
of a Anglosaxon, German or a Russian perspective. But since you have so 
aptly demonstrated your lack of historical awareness allready, I feel no 
interest in exchanging more serious thoughts on these matters with you. 

I would like to close this little educational session with a simple remark: 
Go read a book. Preferably, if you are actually interested in the start of 
the great war, "the Sleepwalkers" by Christopher Clark. It is mandatory 
reading for all undergraduate history students and political science 
students at my university (the Univeristy of Amsterdam) and I am sure you 
could benefit greatly from it. Untill you have read at least that, I feel 
very little need or interest in further debating you. Since untill you have 
at least read that you have not even aquired a rudimentary understanding of 
the causes of the war. 

In closing. If you care at all about assigning blame, which I personally do 
not care about. This because I believe more in Steven Lukes three dimension 
of power paradigm which seeks causes not neccesarily in personal agency (or 
country agency, in so far as that even exists) but in systems of power that 
form and regiment the way in which people and societies think and behave 
(developed in the 70s but still one of the foundational elements of any 
academic political science udergraduate program) .
But if you would like to play the blame game, the Germans are one of the 
last great powers who you should be pointing your finger to. They had the 
least to gain from a war, they had hardly anything to do with the causes of 
the war and the formation of the alliance system that made it a great war 
was more of English making, in which the Germans simply responded by 
re-establishing and strengthening their bonds with their neighbours the 
Austrian/Hungarian empire.
So, if you would like to play the blame game. You might want to point your 
finger in these directions:

Serbian dreams of a pan-Serbian state (or a great Serbia, which turned out 
to be  a terrible idea for all non-Serbian people forced in to that state, 
leading up to the last session of ethnic cleansing we have seen in Europe, 
which we now call the Balkan war.)

Russian interests on the straight and there political dancinig with the 
English over control of it. Which explains the importance the Russians 
ascribed to their sphere of incluence in the Balkan. 

The English who felt threatend because of the rise of Germany as an 
industrial production powerhouse (which was beginning to dwarf and 
massively outcompete the English production) and who plotted to do 
something about that. And by doing so developed the "alliance system" which 
they then had a hand in making this alliance system implode on the Germans. 
 

Hope you read it and become a bit wiser, a bit more educated. Study your 
history, lest it repeats itself... 

Have a nice life. 

With friendly greetings from Amsterdam

PS just because this is the internet, that does not mean you can get away 
with flapping of uneducated opinions. Keep that in mind the next time you 
try and expound on your "beliefs" on whatever the subject may be. Think, do 
I actually know anything about the subject matter I am about the flap of 
on? If not, best to keep quite, study and listen for a while before you 
start talking and making a fool of yourself.

comments.text:
http://spartacus-educational.com/FWWtankosic.htm: "Voja Tankosic, a major 
in the Serbian Army, was one of the founders of the Black Hand group. 
Tankosic worked closely with Dragutin Dimitrijevic, in the 1903 military 
coup that brought King Peter to power. During the Balkan Wars(1912-13) 
Tankosic developed a reputation as an outstanding partisan fighter. He was 
rewarded by becoming the commanding officer of Serbia's guerrilla academy 
at Nis.

Tankosic and Dragutin Dimitrijevic were involved in the plot in 1911 to 
assassinate Emperor Franz Josef. When this failed, they turned their 
attention to the the heir to the throne, Archduke Franz Ferdinand. The men 
were concerned about Ferdinand's plans to grant concessions to the South 
Slavs. The leaders of the Black Hand feared that if this happened, an 
independent Serbian state would be more difficult to achieve.

When Dimitrijevic heard that Archduke Franz Ferdinand was planning to visit 
Sarajevo in June 1914, he sent three members of the Black Hand group, 
Gavrilo Princip, Nedjelko Cabrinovic and Trifko Grabez from Serbia to 
assassinate him. Nikola Pasic, the prime minister of Serbia, Pasic heard 
about the plot and gave instructions for the three men to be arrested. 
However, his orders were not implemented and Archduke Franz Ferdinand was 
assassinated.

Several members of the Black Hand group interrogated by the Austrian 
authorities claimed that three men from Serbia, Tankosic, Dragutin 
Dimitrijevic and Milan Ciganovic had organised the plot. On 25th July, 
1914, the Austro-Hungarian government demanded that the Serbian government 
arrest the men and send them to face trial in Vienna.

On 25th July, 1914, Nikola Pasic, the prime minister of Serbia, told the 
Austro-Hungarian government that he was unable to hand over these three men 
as it "would be a violation of Serbia's Constitution and criminal in law". 
Three days later Austro-Hungarian declared war on Serbia.

Voja Tankosic served in the Serbian Army during the First World War and was 
killed in action during the Serbian retreat in 1915." While the Serbians 
were not exactly happy with the two, they refused to hand them over 
conveying quite a... not good message to Austria.

http://www.firstworldwar.com/source/austrianreport.htm: "Record of the 
District Court at Serajevo, touching the proceedings there instituted 
against Gavrilo Princip and confederates on account of the crime of 
assassination perpetrated on June 28, 1914, on His Imperial and Royal 
Highness the Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria-Este and Her Highness the 
Duchess Sophie of Hohenberg.

Gavrilo Princip, Nedeljko Cabrinovic, Trifko Grabez, Vaso Cubrilovic and 
Cetres Popovic confess that in common with the fugitive Mehemed Mehmedbasic 
they contrived a plot for the murder of the Archduke Franz Ferdinand and, 
armed with bombs and in the case of some of them with Browning pistols, 
laid wait for him on June 28, 1914, on his progress through Serajevo for 
the purpose of carrying out the planned attack.

Nedeljko Cabrinovic confesses that he was the first of the conspirators to 
hurl a bomb against the Archduke's carriage, which missed its mark and 
which on exploding injured only the occupants of the carriage following the 
Archducal motor car.

Gavrilo Princip confesses that he fired two shots from a Browning pistol 
against the Archducal motor car, by which the Archduke Franz Ferdinand and 
the Duchess Sophie of Hohenberg received fatal wounds.

Both perpetrators confess that the act was done with intent to murder.

These confessions have been fully verified by means of the investigations 
which have taken place, and it is established that the deceased Archduke 
Franz Ferdinand and the deceased Duchess Sophie of Hohenberg died as a 
result of the revolver shots fired at them by Gavrilo Princip."

top_comment.text:
I'm not sure it really matters who 'started' the war... it's kinda hard to 
define what the starting point even IS, and as the video explained, pretty 
much every country had some part in it.

I'm personally of the opinion that WW1 was an inevitability. The global 
economy, politics, military situation, etc. basically all led up to a big 
conflict, at some point; sure it could have gone down differently, at a 
slightly different time, for a different reason, but as mentioned 
previously, there have been a lot of conflicts between all these powers and 
really, a big war was pretty much bound to break out.

It's kind of the same argument as what I like to tell people who make "go 
back in time and kill Hitler" jokes... if you killed Hitler in like, 1924 
or such, would it REALLY have stopped WW2? I'm pretty sure Germany would 
have gone to war at some point anyway, maybe a year later, maybe four years 
later, but it was really bound to happen; of course, the actual results and 
details of the war would likely have ended up different; if not for Hitler 
at the helm, the Nazis actually might have WON the war, in Europe.﻿

comments.text:
+kara88bg Probably not. While it's true Germany and Austria-Hungary were 
mostly (though in Germany's case not entirely) left out of the colonization 
game, that wasn't a significant impediment to their economy or growth. 
Overseas imperialism was primarily about prestige not the income (after 
all, why would France try to own most of the 
pretty-much-useless-at-the-time Sahara desert if colonial income was their 
primary concern). Imperial prestige competitions proved fairly easy to 
contain relative to European issues (after all, Britain and France had 
numerous imperial disagreements as did Britain and Russia and yet those 
three found themselves in alliance against Germany) so imperialism probably 
wasn't a major contributing factor. As for Austria, it was trying to expand 
but NOT to keep up with France and Britain in imperialism. Austria-Hungary 
was trying to hold together their multi-ethnic empire by suppressing Serbia 
which was using nationalist ideology to try and convince Austro-Hungarian 
Serbs and other yugoslavian groups to break away. Securing Serbia was an 
attempt to keep their empire whole not an attempt to gain imperial prestige.

+wh4t Spain technically did have a couple of colonies in Africa, 
specifically parts of modern Morocco and Western Sahara as well as 
Equatorial Guinea, but it was a bit player. However, Portugal had far more 
extensive colonies (as did Belgium and the Netherlands in Asia) and yet was 
also minor. Germany held a few colonies, but pretty much all just left-over 
colonies that Britain and France didn't want (like Namibia that's mostly a 
big desert, Cameroon that was jungle no one else wanted, and Togo which was 
tiny). Africa was mostly held by Britain and France, Germany was clearly 
second tier on the same level as bit players like Portugal and Belgium NOT 
on a level with Britain and France. This did annoy the Germans a lot, and 
they did feel cheated given their relative importance in Europe. But 
Germany didn't start a war over the colonial issue. They were worried 
because Russia was modernizing it's army and was allied with France, which 
wanted to retake European territory from Germany (specifically 
Alsace-Lorraine). What Fritz Fischer found was many in the German high 
command were concerned that if Russia's military fully modernized then it 
and France could invade it in Europe and carve up it's territory, so the 
Germans wanted a preventative war to defeat those two powers before Russia 
became too strong to defeat. As it turned out their timing was poor as 
Russia had improved enough already to not be quickly beaten while France 
and the UK combined proved harder to overwhelm than first thought.
comments.author: TheScourge007

+Aturo Firestone Let a German try to explain it: 

Both were called "Kaiser" as main title. Allthough Austria only had a vague 
claim on being "Kaiser" as they traced their title back to the Holy Roman 
Empire itself, which was a elective title (The Austrian monarchs were 
actually just "Archdukes") and since no Kurprince existed to vote them

was more or less made up. 

What really gave them a good claim on being called Emperor though was that 
they had a Personal Union with Hungary, that is why the Austrian Empire was 
also called the "Two Streams Monarchy" or "Dual Crown Monarchy".

Reich, One Kaiser" kind of mentality, so you wouldn't have the national 
Germans call the Austrian Kaiser "Kaiser" but "Emperor" or "Imperator" as 
it is in German, were the Austrians would call their leader Kaiser and the 
German one aswell since Prussia beat Austria to submission in all question 
concerning the national question of Germany.

Both are Emperors and "Kaiser" but the German Emperor would be aknowledged 
as the only "Kaiser" when it comes to German matters.

comments.text:
+Nikola Popovic The Americans mainly talk about Germany when they use 
Kaiser. German-speaking people and other Europeans usually don't AFAIK. 
Also saying that the German Empire was not made up of multiple ethnicities 
highlights that you are not very well aware of the make-up of the 
territory. If you look at the surnames of citizens of the German Empire 
alone you'd see a whole lot of slavic and French surnames. The German 
Empire was keen on letting immigrants into the country as their knowledge 
and skill proved useful for the economy.

Your other mistake is thinking that a German nation is the same thing as 
the German Empire. The German-speaking people in Europe considered 
themselves to be one nation in spirit - divided into countless 
principalities and micro-nations after the 30 year war tore the Holy Roman 
Empire of German Nations apart. There was no such thing as one Germany or 
one German nation. The German people wanted a unified country (something 
that will again play a role with Hitler annexing various German speaking 
regions) and in the 19th century two major principalities emerged, the 
Catholic Austria-Hungary, and the Protestant Prussia who would both manage 
to unify large portions of the German speaking territory while also 
engaging in what German speakers call "Binnenimperialismus", a form of 
imperialism in which one conquers neighboring nations and territories.

+Aturo Firestone As to why both leaders are called "Kaiser" in German, but 
only one is referred to as Kaiser in the USA: Ever since Pipin adopted 
Christianity, in the beginning of the Middle Ages, the emperor, or Kaiser 
of the Holy Roman Empire of German Nations was Catholic and seen as the 
protector of faith. Kaiser being the Germanized form of the word "Caesar" 
(or "cesar" in English). One of the major elements of the 30 year war was 
the appearance of the Protestant creed (or evangelical Christians), 
Christians who were against the Catholic teachings. The northern parts of 
the empire became mostly Protestant, while the south stayed Catholic. Being 
Protestant meant not having to follow the emperor any longer, leading to a 
multitude of liberties. As time went on, the principality of Prussia formed 
in the north and as this Protestant monarchy started to rise militarily and 
economically it set its eyes on defeating the Catholic Austria and claim 
hegemony for itself. After the defeat of Austria, they proceeded to call 
their leader Kaiser as well and their territory henceforth the German 
Empire. (This is relevant as Hitler dubbed his nation the 3rd Reich, or 3rd 
Empire, following the footsteps of the Holy Roman Empire of German Nations 
and the German Empire)

As Prussia was way more prominent than Austria in the political scene (it 
had a fierce military, invested heavily into science and technology, and 
started exporting massive amounts of products), the Americans came to hear 
more about the Kaiser from the German Empire, instead of the Kaiser of 
Austria-Hungary. The reason why Austria-Hungary was, at the time, 
considered a world power was only because of the historical background: 
Their leader was the heir of the Holy Roman Empire of German Nations after 
all. Austria was, however, not prominent in non-European media as it 
basically consisted of an inaccessible mountain region, far off trading 
routes, not a lot of infrastructure, hardly any railways, and it had 
practically no access to an ocean. Naturally, it was far behind Prussia and 
naturally most Americans didn't hear from them, thus the term "Kaiser" got 
associated with the German Empire.

captions.text:
Hi, I'm John Green, this is Crash Course World
History, and today we continue our discussion

of how a regional conflict became World War
I. We're also going to look at who started

the war and although no one nation is truly
to blame, some nations are more to blame than others.

Like America, for once? Blameless. Well, not
totally blameless. Largely blameless.

Mr. Green, Mr. Green! That's easy, the Germans
started the war.

Well, Me from the Past, as it happens many
historians and British politicians would agree

with you. I mean, you have an opinion that can be
defended. And I can't wait for you to defend it.

Uhh... maybe they just, like, really liked war? I'm
not really in the defending positions business,

Mr. Green, I'm more in the like, bold proclamations
business.

Yes, Me from the Past, noted. But it turns
out, there's more to life than that.

So the topic of who started World War I remains
one of the most controversial and interesting

topics to discuss in World History, not least because,
you know, we'd like to avoid having another one.

But in general, when we talk about World Wars,
as when we talk about World Cups, we pretty
quickly end up discussing Germany.

The idea that the root cause of World War
I was Germany, or more specifically, German

militarism, continues to be popular. This
has been the case ever since the 1960s when

this historian, Fritz Fisher, identified Germany
as the chief cause of the war. But Germany's

guilt for the war was also written into the
Versailles Peace Treaty, in article 231, and

most of you will be familiar with the idea
that anger over that clause its incumbent
debts helped lead to Hitler's rise.

Also, pretty much however you slice it Germany
was definitely responsible for starting World

War II, and looking back that made it more
plausible that they would have also stated

World War I, because, you know, they had a
history of starting wars. To be fair, the

definition of a Western European nation is
"has a history starting wars."
Unless you're the Swiss.
Cue the Switzereel, Stan!

Yeah okay, but the thing is attributing characteristics
like militarism or authoritarianism to entire

national populations is a little problematic.
Also one nation's militarism is another nation's

strong national defense, and when you live
in the country, as I do, that spends more

on defense than any other nation, it's probably
not that good of an idea to call people militaristic.

There's just something about that broad-brush
painting of an entire nation sharing a particular

characteristic that feels a little bit propaganda-y.
Also, it wasn't just Germans who were militaristic

in 1914. The idea of "the glory of war" was
a very popular concept all over Europe, and

really there's no evidence that the German
people of 1914 were any more or less militaristic

than the French or the Russians, They all
had poetry that celebrated heroic sacrifice
and dying for the Mother and/or Fatherland.

That's not usually and. Maybe, though. I'm
gonna stay open minded.

But there's another problem with the whole
idea that the Germans were more eager for

war than anyone else in Europe. That argument
relies a lot on the behavior of Kaiser Wilhelm

II, the German leader, and the Kaiser did
make some pretty bellicose and stupid public

statements, which in turn made people fear
that Germans were eager for war. So Wilhelm

became kind of a stand-in for German aggression,
a literal cartoon villain, upon whom the world,

especially the English, could project their
stereotypes.

So I would argue that the German character
isn't to blame for World War I, and in fact

no national character has ever been to blame
for any war. But I am not going to let the
Germans off the hook entirely.

So you will remember that Germany offered
the so-called "blank check" that Germans would

always support Austro-Hungarians' ultimatum
to Serbia. And in some ways this empowering

by Germany's support encouraged Austria's
foreign minister Berchtold to behave as recklessly

as possible, under the mistaken impression that
this is what the Germans wanted him to do.

So basically, Austria thought that Germany
wanted a war, so they were like, "Oh, we'll

just behave really recklessly and we'll give
the Germans the war they've been so excited

about." But the Germans were offering the
Austrians the assurance of support in the
hopes that it wouldn't lead to war.

So you could argue that in fact most of the
blame for starting World War I should fall

on the shoulders of the Austrians, after all,
they were the ones who issued the ultimatum

to Serbia, and they were the first to declare
war, although only against Serbia. But, the

Germans were the first to declare war on a
major power, Russia, on August 1st, and the

German advance on France through Belgium is
what brought Britain into the war. And those

are pretty solid arguments that Germany turned
the conflict from, you know, a regional thing

in the Balkans, which isn't unprecedented,
to like this big pan-European war.

But I don't think we're done assigning blame,
because we didn't just have a pan-European
war, we had a world war. Russia.

Now you'll remember that of all the major
powers, Russia was the first to mobilize its

massive army, and it was Russia's mobilization that
drew Germany, France, and Britain into the war.

Putin is looking at me, isn't he, Stan. I'm
just trying to--ah! you so scary!

Stan, can you please make Mr. Putin go away,
I'm just trying to talk about history, I'm
not talking about any current conflicts.

And it makes me nervous to say this, but there
was really no good reason for Russia to mobilize

in the first place. I mean, when Austria declared
war on Serbia on July 28th, the Austrians

could not mobilize their own troops for two
weeks, because they were on harvest break.

I mean, if we've learned anything about agriculture,
it's that it's hard to have a large-scale

war without it, so we can't go to war until
all the wheat has been farmed.

But even if Austria had mobilized and attacked
immediately, their initial plan was an attack

on Belgrade, not Russia, which by the way
was called somewhat confusingly, Plan B. Now,

Vienna did have a plan to mobilize against
both Serbia and Russia, but they never used

it. But even if Austria had launched an all-out
attack on Russia, Russia had begun its pre-mobilization,

the period preparatory to war, on July 25th,
and while I usually don't care about dates,

with the start of World War I, very important,
because July 25th was before the Serbs had
even responded to the Austrian ultimatum.

And just as a general rule, it's hard to play
the blameless victim when you're moving all

of your troops to the border. Hey, why are
you here again, Putin?

So here we have Austrians and Germans receiving
reports of Russian troops massing on their

borders, and you know, that seems kind of
like war. A lot of it comes down to how you

understand Russia's period preparatory to
war. I mean, do you focus on the "period preparatory",

or do you focus on the "to war"? Regardless,
Russia became the first power to actually
put its war machine into motion.
Let's go to the Thought Bubble.

So talking about Russia leads us to some of
the more meta arguments about the causes of

World War I because it's difficult to understand
what Russia was doing when it mobilized without

trying to understand why they mobilized. After
all, an Austrian attack on Serbia was hardly

an existential threat to Russia, I mean, look
at the map. Russia's huge, and at the time,

probably had the largest army in Europe, if
not the world. So why would they care about

what was likely to be a skirmish on the Bosnian
border?

Well, here's where geo-politics and history
come in. So, looking at the map, you can see

that the Balkans are right next to the Dardanelles,
the straits that give access to the Black

Sea. Russia needed to maintain influence there
in order to ensure traffic through those straits,

especially if the Ottomans were going to form
an alliance with the Germans, which they did.

Also, at least in its own estimation, Russia
was in danger of becoming a laughingstock

in European politics: their humiliating loss
to Japan in the Russo-Japanese War was followed

by Russia's inability to stop Austria from
annexing Bosnia from the Ottomans in 1908,

and that was the event that sparked Serbia's
drive to expand its own territory. Its history

of prior weakness meant that Russia's foreign
policy makers feared that without some decisive

action, Russia wouldn't be taken seriously
anymore.

In the wake of Austria's ultimatum, Russian
foreign minister Sazonov concluded that Russia,

quote, "Could not remain a passive spectator
whilst a Slavonic people was being trampled

down. If Russia failed to fulfill her historic
mission, she would be considered a decadent

state and would henceforth have to take second
place among the powers...if at this critical

juncture, the Serbs were abandoned to their
fate, Russian prestige in the Balkans would
collapse utterly."
Thanks, Thought Bubble.

So judging from what we just learned in the
Thought Bubble, it was really the Ottomans.

If they could have just stopped Austria from
annexing Bosnia in the first place, none of

this would have happened. And if I may go
a little further back, there wouldn't have

even been an Ottoman Empire without the stupid
Romans. And of course the Roman Empire was

largely dependent upon constant expansion
and looting, so if only the Gauls could have
defeated Caesar, none of this would have happened.

In short, no wonder Caesar was assassinated,
he was about to start World War I in 1900 years.

I bring that up because that's the tricky
thing about the blame game. You can trace

the causes of World War I back a bunch of
ways. I mean, I can't think of anyone who

you can't at least partially assign blame
to - well, I mean except the Mongols.

Actually you know what, if they'd just kept
control of Russia, probably no World War I.

Anyway, all of this only scratches the surface
of the arguments about who's to blame for

World War I. I mean, I haven't dealt with
stuff like the alliance system or European

imperialism, or you often hear about the naval
rivalry between Britain and Germany, and then

there are the ideological causes, like nationalism,
and the Social Darwinist thinking that led

people to believe that war was a natural and
inevitable state of human affairs.

You can tell all those origin stories of the
Great War, and they're important, but ours

centers on diplomatic history. There are a
few reasons for this, first, the decision

to go to war was ultimately in the hands of
a very small group of diplomats. I mean, even

in the most democratic countries, Britain
and France, popular opinion didn't force mobilization.

Also, in most countries that's still the case.
It's still diplomats who decide whether to

go to war. So understanding what makes governments
and diplomats decide to go to war is very important.

But looking at the diplomatic causes of the
war also reveals something to us about the

pitfalls of writing history. I mean diplomats
are famous for keeping pretty detailed records

of their dealings, both at the time and in
retrospect, and then historians have to sift

through all these sources and make choices
about which ones to emphasize. And sometimes,

even which ones to believe, because of course,
often these sources are in direct conflict.

Now, I'm no historian, but in creating this
episode, we had to make choices that many

of you will disagree with. Either because
you don't think we gave enough evidence or

because you don't like the things that we
emphasized, and that's great. It's these constructive

and critical conversations that lead us to
dig deeper, to consult more primary sources,

to read more broadly, and that in turn leads
to a richer understanding of the world and
a more engaged life.

All that noted, the alliance system was certainly
important and I'm sure you'll be discussing
it in your classes, and in comments.

Thank you for watching, I'll see you next
week.

As we say in my hometown, don't forget to
